profile_data.summary:
My curiosity and love for analysis leads me to find data insights that are often overlooked. During my first industry role I leveraged this quality to increase Media.net's revenue, both by saving time through automation and also by identifying patterns in the user and financial data. To satiate my thirst for knowledge and explore a more statistical approach to data, I decided to pursue a Master's degree in Computer Science with a concentration in Data Science.

I have a penchant for psychology and believe that mental well-being is an important factor for being successful in life. Championing this philosophy, I had undertaken a research project under Professor Andrew McCallum last semester. The project had enabled me to research the correlation between student performance and mental health. My task is to gather raw  data through sensors, EMAs, etc. and develop machine learning models to predict various activities. The project is very open-ended leaving a lot of room for creativity. This research continued as a summer research internship at UMass. During my time at the internship I developed used Classical Machine Learning Models and LSTMs to predict stress levels using the Student Life Data, thus creating a basis for further potential studies.

The fields that intrigue me the most are Data Science, Machine Learning, Data engineering and Software Engineering; however, I am open to any quantitative based internships. Please feel free to contact me if you want to learn more about my research or projects.

Specialties : Machine Learning, Neural Networks, C++, Python, Data basses.

education.degreeName: Master of Science - MS (Specialization in Data Science)

publications.name: Dynamic clustering via branched deep learning enhances personalization of stress prediction from mobile sensor data
publications.description: College students experience ever-increasing levels of stress, leading to a wide range of healthproblems. In this context, monitoring and predicting students’ stress levels is crucial and, fortunately,made possible by the growing support for data collection via mobile devices. However, predictingstress levels from mobile phone data remains a challenging task, and off-the-shelf deep learningmodels are inapplicable or inefficient due to data irregularity, inter-subject variability, and the “coldstart problem”. To overcome these challenges, we developed a platform named Branched CALM-Netthat aims to predict students’ stress levels through dynamic clustering in a personalized manner.This is the first platform that leverages the branching technique in a multitask setting to achievepersonalization and continuous adaptation. Our method achieves state-of-the-art performance inpredicting student stress from mobile sensor data collected as part of the Dartmouth StudentLifestudy, with a ROC AUC 37% higher and a PR AUC surpassing that of the nearest baseline models. Inthe cold-start online learning setting, Branched CALM-Net outperforms other models, attaining anaverage F1 score of 87% with just 1 week of training data for a new student, which shows it is reliableand effective at predicting stress levels from mobile data.

publications.name: Personalized Student Stress Prediction with Deep Multitask Network
publications.description: With the growing popularity of wearable devices, the ability to utilize physiological data collected from these devices to predict the wearer's mental state such as mood and stress suggests great clinical applications, yet such a task is extremely challenging. In this paper, we present a general platform for personalized predictive modeling of behavioral states like students' level of stress. Through the use of Auto-encoders and Multi-Task learning we extend the prediction of stress to both sequences of passive sensor data and high-level covariates. Our model outperforms the state-of-the-art in the prediction of stress level from mobile sensor data, obtaining a 45.6% improvement in F1 score on the StudentLife dataset.

certifications.name: XAA101 - Designing Reliable and Robust AI Systems

projects.description:
•Currently building a Hybrid Reverse Dictionary that uses a database driven approach to get a result set for a given input and then sort the result with most relevant results up top through Machine Learning and Text Similarity.
•Using the WorldNet database Reverse Mappings of Senses (words) are created pre-runtime and queried during runtime. The result set of this query is expanded through Hyponyms and Hypernyms if required. The Senses, SynSets (Definitions of a Word) and the Input Phrases are stemmed to reduce inflected words to their base Stem.
projects.title: Hybrid Reverse Dictionary

projects.description:
•	Developing an algorithm that derives tight probabilistic bounds on statistical properties (mean, median, variance, etc.) of samples drawn from an unknown distribution. 
•	Creating a library using Python and Seaborn to automate various statistical plots for bounds based on the Central Limit Theorem, Bootstrap, Chernoff-Hoeffding Inequality, etc.
projects.title: Probabilistic Bounds (Erik Learned Miller)

projects.description:
• This project explores better ways for optimizing Hyper-parameters in a 2-Layer Fully connected Neural Network. The project explores novel techniques for hyper-parameter optimization problem. 
• The technique uses Poisson Disc sampling along with heuristics to get better Neural Net configurations. On evaluating the performance of the techniques, it is found that the algorithm out performs Grid Search consistently.
projects.title: Hyper-parameter Optimization with Poisson Disc sampling and Heuristics

projects.description:
